metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 1km/5day compositing Leaf Area Index (LAI) product of Heihe River Basin, 2015
metadata.description: The 5-day Lai synthesis results in 2015 are provided by the 1 km / 5-day Lai data set of Heihe River Basin. The data set is constructed by using the data of Terra / MODIS, Aqua / MODIS, as well as the domestic satellites fy3a / MERSI and fy3b / MERSI to construct the multi-source remote sensing data set with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a time resolution of 5 days. Multi-source remote sensing data sets can provide more angles and more observations than a single sensor in a limited time. However, due to the difference of on orbit running time and performance of sensors, the observation quality of multi-source data sets is uneven. Therefore, in order to make more effective use of multi-source data sets, the algorithm first classifies the quality of multi-source data sets, which can be divided into first level data, second level data and third level data according to the observation rationality. The third level data are observations polluted by thin clouds and are not used for calculation. The purpose of quality evaluation and classification is to provide the basis for the selection of the optimal data set and the design of inversion algorithm flow. Leaf area index product inversion algorithm is designed to distinguish mountain land and vegetation type, using different neural network inversion model. Based on global DEM map and surface classification map, PROSAIL model is used for continuous vegetation such as grassland and crops, and gost model is used for forest and mountain vegetation. Using the reference map generated by the measured ground data of the forests in the upper reaches of Heihe River and the oasis in the middle reaches, and scaling up the corresponding high-resolution reference map to 1km resolution, compared with the Lai product, the product has a good correlation between the farmland and the forest area and the reference value, and the overall accuracy basically meets the accuracy threshold of 0.5%, 20% specified by GCOS. By cross comparing this product with Lais products such as MODIS, geov1 and glass, the accuracy of this Lai product is better than that of similar products compared with reference value. In a word, the synthetic Lai data set of 1km / 5 days in Heihe River Basin comprehensively uses multi-source remote sensing data to improve the estimation accuracy and time resolution of Lai parameter products, so as to better serve the application of remote sensing data products.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: The Earth’s surface radiation budget is an essential parameter for estimation of the surface energy budget and is used for various applications, including weather prediction, monitoring and analysis of climate, and terrestrial ecological and hydrological systems. As a particularly important component of the surface radiation budget, surface solar irradiance (SSI) is the primary source of energy for the Earth’s surface; it controls the total energy exchange between the atmosphere and the land‐ocean surface and also serves as a key driving force for evapotranspiration, plant growth, and related processes. SSI data with large geographical coverage (up to global) and high spatiotemporal resolution can be obtained from satellite data. Estimating the surface solar radiation using satellite remote sensing techniques is essential not only for complementing the sparse network of surface station measurements, but also for verifying climate model output and reanalysis data.
research objective: In this paper, a new satellite‐derived approach for obtaining instantaneous surface solar irradiance (SSI) by combining Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) and Multifunctional Transport Satellite (MTSAT) data is presented and validated using one year pyranometer measurements from five stations in northern China.
challenges: However, in mountainous areas the results need further refinement.
methods: Here we use MTSAT data to capture the changes of cloud fields in the atmosphere and use MODIS products to obtain the dynamic aerosol loading, water vapor content, surface reflectance, and other information. Meanwhile, on the basis of instantaneous retrieval results, the calculation of hourly average SSI is also explored.
dataset: Two types of satellite data were used in this study: polar‐orbiting satellite products from multispectral MODIS, and geostationary meteorological satellite data from the Multifunctional Transport Satellite MTSAT1R. The pyranometer data for validation come from five meteorological stations where the SSI is measured alongside other meteorological parameters. These stations are the Guantao and Daxing experimental stations in north China and the Yingke oasis station, Huazhaizi desert station, and A’rou freeze‐thaw observation station in northwest China.
findings: The preliminary validation demonstrates that both instantaneous and hourly SSIs can be produced accurately over northern China using this approach, and the retrieval quality of hourly SSI data is slightly better than that of instantaneous SSI data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that utilizes multiple satellite sensors to improve observation quality in eco-hydrological studies?
Example.Answer: A data collection method utilizes multiple satellite sensors such as Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and FY3A/MERSI to create a composite dataset with a spatial resolution of 1km and temporal resolution of 5 days. This approach helps in obtaining more angles and observations than a single sensor could provide, allowing for improved observation quality in eco-hydrological studies.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in using multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research is the poor availability of such observations, which hinders progress in understanding and modeling eco-hydrological processes across heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a multiscale dataset obtained from eco-hydrological research in an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of a multiscale dataset obtained from eco-hydrological research is the dataset from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) project, which includes a flux observation matrix, an eco-hydrological sensor network, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data, and ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial in eco-hydrological research as they allow for the capturing of processes at different scales, which is important for understanding the complex interactions and dynamics within heterogeneous surfaces. The HiWATER experiment uses a multiscale observation system including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations to address the challenge of limited multiscale data availability.

Definition.Question: How does the neural network method contribute to the inversion of Leaf Area Index (LAI) products in different terrains?
Definition.Answer: The neural network method aids in the inversion of LAI products by utilizing different models for various terrains. For instance, the PROSAIL model is used for continuous vegetation like grasslands and crops, while the GOST model is applied to forest and mountain vegetation. This distinction allows for more accurate representation and processing of LAI data in diverse environmental conditions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between the HiWATER experiment and the approach for estimating surface solar irradiance (SSI) using satellite data?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment employs a hierarchical instrumentation approach with flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, the SSI estimation method combines MODIS and MTSAT satellite data to derive surface irradiance, focusing on capturing atmospheric changes and dynamic aerosol loading for broader geographical coverage. While HiWATER focuses on a nested scale for detailed local observations, the SSI method emphasizes satellite-derived atmospheric and surface reflectance data for larger areas.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the use of satellite-derived surface solar irradiance (SSI) data for advancing the understanding of surface energy budgets in different geographical regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite-derived SSI data, integrated from sources like MODIS and MTSAT, provide crucial insights into surface energy budgets by offering extensive geographical coverage and high spatiotemporal resolution. This data is vital for applications in weather prediction and climate monitoring. In particular, it helps validate and enhance the accuracy of climate models and reanalysis data. However, the approach requires refinement in mountainous areas to improve retrieval accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in the field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a grand challenge due to the complexity of capturing eco-hydrological processes across diverse landscapes and scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the quality assessment and grading of multi-source remote sensing data necessary for effective utilization in leaf area index (LAI) estimation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The quality assessment and grading of multi-source remote sensing data are necessary to address the varying observational quality due to differences in sensor performance and operational times, ensuring the selection of optimal datasets for LAI estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on data quality and accuracy when using multi-source remote sensing data instead of relying on a single sensor for leaf area index (LAI) estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using multi-source remote sensing data, such as combining Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and FY3A/MERSI, improves the estimation accuracy and time resolution of LAI parameters by providing more angles and observations. However, due to differences in sensor performance and operation times, the quality of multi-source data can be inconsistent. Quality grading is necessary to ensure optimal dataset selection for LAI inversion, enhancing the overall accuracy compared to single-source data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using satellite-derived surface solar irradiance (SSI) data in comparison to ground-based pyranometer measurements for monitoring climate and ecological systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using satellite-derived SSI data, such as from MODIS and MTSAT, provides extensive geographical coverage and high spatiotemporal resolution, complementing the sparse network of ground-based pyranometer measurements. This approach enhances the ability to verify climate models and reanalysis data, though results in mountainous areas may require further refinement. The combination of satellite data enables accurate estimation of SSI, which is crucial for understanding surface energy exchanges and driving ecological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind creating a multiscale dataset for eco-hydrological processes in the Heihe Watershed?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface, which is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. The HiWATER experiment facilitates this by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to utilize multi-source remote sensing data for estimating leaf area index (LAI) in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using multi-source remote sensing data allows for improved estimation accuracy of LAI parameters by providing more observation angles and increased frequency of observations within a limited timeframe. This approach also helps in selecting optimal datasets and designing retrieval algorithm processes tailored for different vegetation types and terrains.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in calibrating sensors and controlling the quality of multiscale datasets used in eco-hydrological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field, all observational data are carefully quality controlled throughout the sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation stages. This involves ensuring the reliability of instruments like eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can different models be applied to retrieve leaf area index (LAI) in varied landscapes such as grassland, cropland, and forest areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To retrieve LAI in varied landscapes, different models are used such as the PROSAIL model for continuous vegetation like grassland and cropland, and the slope GOST model for forest and mountain areas. This approach allows for the distinction between plains and mountains and the use of appropriate models for different vegetation types.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure the accuracy and validation of surface solar irradiance (SSI) data obtained from satellite remote sensing?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodologies involve using MTSAT data to capture changes in cloud fields and MODIS products to obtain dynamic aerosol loading, water vapor content, and surface reflectance. The instantaneous retrieval results are further refined to calculate hourly average SSI, and the data is validated using pyranometer measurements from various meteorological stations.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous environments?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data is enabled by the use of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and a sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers are employed.

Enablement.Question: How do quality control processes enhance the reliability of datasets in eco-hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control processes enhance the reliability of datasets by ensuring careful calibration of sensors, meticulous data collection, thorough data processing, and careful generation of datasets. These processes are crucial to maintaining the integrity and accuracy of the data collected during eco-hydrological research.

Enablement.Question: What technological solutions enable the accurate retrieval of surface solar irradiance data from satellite observations?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate retrieval of surface solar irradiance data is enabled by combining data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) and the Multifunctional Transport Satellite (MTSAT). This approach allows for capturing changes in cloud fields, dynamic aerosol loading, water vapor content, and surface reflectance, which are essential for calculating instantaneous and hourly average surface solar irradiance.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving high-quality multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in achieving high-quality multiscale observations arise due to the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a significant hindrance in the field. The complexity of capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces requires a comprehensive instrumentation strategy, such as the hierarchically nested scales used in HiWATER, to obtain multi-scale and multidisciplinary data.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to use different models for different vegetation types in the design of LAI inversion algorithms?
Expectation.Answer: It is important to use different models for different vegetation types because the structural and ecological characteristics of vegetation, such as those found in grasslands, crops, forests, and mountainous regions, vary significantly. By distinguishing between mountain and plain areas and using tailored models like the PROSAIL for continuous vegetation and the slope GOST model for forest and mountain vegetation, the LAI inversion algorithm can more accurately estimate the leaf area index, thus improving the product's precision and applicability.

Judgmental.Question: How do hierarchical nested scales in the HiWATER experiment contribute to the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Hierarchical nested scales in the HiWATER experiment allow for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by using a diverse array of instruments, such as eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, in various landscapes. This approach provides detailed and multiscale data that are essential for understanding interactions in the oasis-desert system, thereby addressing the challenge of limited multiscale observations and improving the overall data quality and availability.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges are associated with using satellite data to estimate surface solar irradiance (SSI) in mountainous areas, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Estimating SSI in mountainous areas poses challenges due to terrain variability, which affects the accuracy of satellite-derived data. The results in such areas require further refinement to address these challenges. Combining multiple data sources, such as MODIS and MTSAT, and incorporating ground-based validation using pyranometer measurements can help improve the accuracy and address the complexities introduced by mountainous terrain.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multiscale observations can be effectively managed when dealing with heterogeneous surfaces in eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: Multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research can be effectively managed through the use of experiments like HiWATER, which addresses this challenge by utilizing instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales. This approach involves capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes with a sparse network, including the use of eddy covariance towers, meteorological stations, and various remote sensing missions.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the best way to ensure the quality of data collected from multiple satellite sensors with varying performance characteristics.
Assertion.Answer: Ensuring the quality of data collected from multiple satellite sensors can involve a quality grading system for multisource datasets, as demonstrated in the LAI data collection. This system classifies data based on observational rationality and excludes data affected by thin cloud contamination from calculations. This method helps in selecting the optimal dataset for retrieval algorithm design.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data quality control measures applied in eco-hydrological datasets and evaluate their effectiveness in ensuring reliable data collection.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data quality control measures include sensor calibration, data collection processes, data processing, and dataset generation. These measures are applied to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the collected data. By using such rigorous quality control protocols, the datasets are maintained at high standards, which are crucial for accurate eco-hydrological analysis and modeling.
